text: I'd like to see you step in the cow
patty before you leave someone get that
on tape I'm Nicholas Kristof at the New
York Times I periodically write about
agriculture systems and food in ways
that are frankly kind of depressing but
today I'm here with a happy food story
I'm here in Yamhill Oregon my hometown
along with one of my high school buddies
Bob Danson and a local dairy men on his
dairy and my favorite fact about Bob is
that he has individual names and
recognizes all his 400 plus head of
dairy cattle so these ladies right here
whatever is in there their names Reba
would be the first gal here and the one
behind her is Dana and Reba and Dana
frankly it may seem odd that bob is on a
first-name basis with hundreds of
carriers well ladies here we go but that
chumminess is a reminder that American
agriculture doesn't have to be
industrial to be efficient or make money
livestock don't have to be abused to be
profitable for their owners come on
ladies come on Bob is business is built
on treating his animals not as widgets
but it's co-workers even family members
because that is how he sees them they're
taking care of me I'm taking care of
them so even if you don't have a
connection to an individual cow you
appreciate what she's doing for you
Bob's cow spend most of their time
outside where they eat grass enjoy
sunshine and are free to roam the
pastures that's a contrast to many
larger industrial dairies work now spend
much of their lives and huge barns
eating grain that sounds efficient but
in fact the industrial Gary's are
discovering that it isn't so some are
moving back to the traditional model but
the trend is to get cows back outside
not only on organic but but for for
conventional also
there's so much evidence that there's so
much happier and so much healthier out
there one of the big worries about
industrial agriculture is the overuse of
antibiotics Bob used to buy into the
conventional view that antibiotics are
necessary when he shifted to organic
production eight years ago he worried
that halting the use of antibiotics
would leave his cows sick it didn't work
out that way I found no difference as a
matter of fact maybe an improvement in
utter health for not doing it because I
think sometimes you actually we're
putting pathogens in the utter when you
were inserting the antibiotics so so
that became obvious to me right away
that that was a program that I shouldn't
have been buying into if you drink a
glass of organic valley milk it may come
from one of these cows well you may not
know her name
Bob sure dyes that black cow right there
that's Harold's mom let's share modern
agribusiness has lost its soul but
farmers like Bob find a way to compete
on family farms that just exude soul and
Bob's operation isn't just soulful it's
also sustainably healthy as a business
for humans and cows alike if the cow is
in a maximal health and their maximum
contentedness she's profitable so I
don't even really manage my my farm so
much from a fiscal standpoint is from a
cow standpoint because I know that if I
take care of those cows the bottom line
will take care of itself
